@stephenxs So this issue exists because we call ```get_buffer_pool_stats``` and ```clear_buffer_pool_stats``` in ```generateBufferPoolWatermarkCounterIdList``` that you want to postpone in this change?
Why not using ```sai_query_stats_capability``` which tells whether object supports READ, READ_CLEAR capabilities?

> @stephenxs So this issue exists because we call `get_buffer_pool_stats` and `clear_buffer_pool_stats` in `generateBufferPoolWatermarkCounterIdList` that you want to postpone in this change? Why not using `sai_query_stats_capability` which tells whether object supports READ, READ_CLEAR capabilities?

@stepanblyschak 
Thanks for the suggestion. Yes, that's the motivation but I'm afraid `sai_query_stats_capability` is not able to satisfy the requirement.
```
/**
 * @brief Query statistics capability for statistics bound at object level
 *
 * @param[in] switch_id SAI Switch object id
 * @param[in] object_type SAI object type
 * @param[inout] stats_capability List of implemented enum values, and the statistics modes (bit mask) supported per value
 *
 * @return #SAI_STATUS_SUCCESS on success, #SAI_STATUS_BUFFER_OVERFLOW if lists size insufficient, failure status code on error
 */
```
`sai_query_stats_capability` provides the ability to query capability on a per-object-type basis. 
However, it is required to do it on a per-object basis here. Eg. on some platforms, `SAI_BUFFER_POOL_STAT_XOFF_ROOM_WATERMARK_BYTES` can be fetched on `ingress_lossless_pool` only. (This code is not here for now. It had been there but was reverted because of the bug we try to fix by this PR. We need to re-add it after the bug is fixed.)

3. Change cbfnhghandler to cbfnhgorch

6. Retain nhgorch.h/cpp as it is.

IMO, nghorch and cbfnghorch must be separate. I understand the template related changes but should not be calling each other.

> > @prsunny I've made those suggested changes.
> > The changes to the original nhgorch now mostly consist of the following:
> > 
> > * Code moved to the template classes
> > * A few calls to cbfnhgorch when looking up next hop groups
> > * Some fields renamed to better reflect the combined code (e.g. next hop group members may now be next hops or next hop groups, so renamed m_nh_key to m_key).
> > 
> > All these changes are now a lot easier to follow in the code, as there's less churn
> 
> IMO, nghorch and cbfnghorch must be separate. I understand the template related changes but should not be calling each other.

We can't really have CbfNhgOrch not using NhgOrch as members of a CbfNhg can be NHGs on their own, which NhgOrch handles. A CbfNhg needs to validate that such a NHG exists and increase/decrease its ref count.

The very best we could do would be to make NhgOrch not call CbfNhgOrch as it currently does to increase/decrease ref count or check existance/grab a CbfNhg as NhgOrch right now acts as a proxy for CbfNhgOrch in RouteOrch. This would put some pressure on RouteOrch having to query 2 orchs for NHGs but I agree it's for the best as the code stands right now.

Detailed changes of each file
cfgmgr/buffer_pool_mellanox.lua
- handle profile list tables. don't need to count the number of egress_profile_list as the number of ports because we handle profile list tables now.
- handle accelerate the buffer pool table handling at beginning of switch
- count number of admin up 8-lane ports because they have different reserved sizes which is not exposed to sonic
  originally, we count number of all 8-lane ports. now we will reclaim them as well so we need to count admin-up ports.

cfgmgr/buffermgr.cpp: the same change as that in 201911
- remove lossless PG 3-4 when port is admin down and the profile matches the default profile of the port

cfgmgr/buffermgrd.cpp: support loading JSON file containing zero pools and profiles definition from CLI via -j option
orchagent/bufferorch.cpp
- remove watermark counter id list for a pool when it is removed - the zero pool will be removed once the last admin-down port is admin-up

orchagent/orch.cpp
- change the severity of log unable to parse the reference. it is because of order and will succeed once the pool exists
- add functions for converting ID lists to bitmaps

orchagent/portsorch.cpp: fetch the maximum queues and priority groups supported on the port
tests/test_buffer_dynamic.py
- change the cable length to a non-zero one
- add test cases for reclaiming buffer: queues should also be reclaimed when a port is admin down

cfgmgr/buffermgrdyn.cpp
-  TBD

from gcc man 2nd paragraph:
```
       -fprofile-arcs
           Add code so that program flow arcs are instrumented.  During execution the program records how many times each branch and call is executed and
           how many times it is taken or returns.  On targets that support constructors with priority support, profiling properly handles constructors,
           destructors and C++ constructors (and destructors) of classes which are used as a type of a global variable.

           When the compiled program exits it saves this data to a file called auxname.gcda for each source file.  The data may be used for profile-
           directed optimizations (-fbranch-probabilities), or for test coverage analysis (-ftest-coverage).  Each object file's auxname is generated from
           the name of the output file, if explicitly specified and it is not the final executable, otherwise it is the basename of the source file.  In
           both cases any suffix is removed (e.g. foo.gcda for input file dir/foo.c, or dir/foo.gcda for output file specified as -o dir/foo.o).
```

actually, we have tried souce code on local(with artifict vs docker) also, not work either. 
and from gcov principle we can find the root cause:
a) In the executable process file, call gcov_init to initialize the statistical data area before entering the main function, and register gcov_exit as exit handlers;

b) When the user-side code calls exit, it will call gcov_exit, which will continue to call the __gcov_flush function to output statistical data to the *.gcda file.

From the implementation principle of gcov, it can be known that if the user process does not call exit() to exit, the coverage statistics will not be obtained, and there will be no way to generate reports. Once the background service program is started, it rarely exits actively. In order to solve this problem, we can register a signal handler for the program under test to handle common forced exit signals such as SIGINT, SIGQUIT, SIGTERM, and actively call the exit or __gcov_flush function in the signal processing function to output statistics result.

> > From the implementation principle of gcov, it can be known that if the user process does not call exit() to exit, the coverage statistics will not be obtained, and there will be no way to generate reports. Once the background service program is started, it rarely exits actively. In order to solve this problem, we can register a signal handler for the program under test to handle common forced exit signals such as SIGINT, SIGQUIT, SIGTERM, and actively call the exit or __gcov_flush function in the signal processing function to output statistics result
